content.raw:
Hey Nima,

With the current version of the plugin, it would be very difficult to call update() in parse() because update() accesses certain member variables in Agent and parse() is run by the server thread. It would mean that we have to use a mutex everytime the Agent object is accessed by both the gamestate thread and server thread, otherwise it would not be thread safe. I prefer the current version, where the only data structure shared between threads is effector.socketIDMessageMap. 

As for the message overwriting problem, we can change it so that messages appended to socketIDMessageMap everytime parse() is called.
content.html:
Hey Nima,

With the current version of the plugin, it would be very difficult to call update() in parse() because update() accesses certain member variables in Agent and parse() is run by the server thread. It would mean that we have to use a mutex everytime the Agent object is accessed by both the gamestate thread and server thread, otherwise it would not be thread safe. I prefer the current version, where the only data structure shared between threads is effector.socketIDMessageMap.

As for the message overwriting problem, we can change it so that messages appended to socketIDMessageMap everytime parse() is called.

content.raw: Thats pretty cool, thanks.
content.html: Thats pretty cool, thanks.

content.raw: If we do not wait between sending the init message and the joint effectors message, the init message will be overwritten and the agent will not be initialized. The other reason is that in this test, right after initialization of the client and sending the messages, the client will be closed and will be disconnected. Both of these two issues can be solved by adding some sleep system call. But I think it is better to see the initMessage as an event to alter the simulator state, this can be done by adding Update in parse() callback.
content.html: If we do not wait between sending the init message and the joint effectors message, the init message will be overwritten and the agent will not be initialized. The other reason is that in this test, right after initialization of the client and sending the messages, the client will be closed and will be disconnected. Both of these two issues can be solved by adding some sleep system call. But I think it is better to see the initMessage as an event to alter the simulator state, this can be done by adding Update in parse() callback.

update.description:
This is a Effector class. It uses the Server class architecture and implemented its Parse(). Retrieving effectors values form messages has been implemented using s-expression library. The description of data structures, accessors and methods can be found in EffectorParser.hh.

Also, effector messages that are used in Simspark simulator can be found in following link:
[http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Effectors](http://simspark.sourceforge.net/wiki/index.php/Effectors)
update.title: Nima_actionparser

content.raw:
if s-expression library tries to access the elements that don't exist, this may cause crash in s-expression library, we should handle that problem. For your example (unum 5)  we will never have problem , since we check the unum, and then we just check the next one. but I can tell you for example if a team  send (unum) intensionally we will have a problem. In a future, after integration, we can think how to handle these situations.
I am going to commit the remained parts of effector and effector_test, then please merge to that.
content.html: if s-expression library tries to access the elements that don't exist, this may cause crash in s-expression library, we should handle that problem. For your example (unum 5) we will never have problem , since we check the unum, and then we just check the next one. but I can tell you for example if a team send (unum) intensionally we will have a problem. In a future, after integration, we can think how to handle these situations. I am going to commit the remained parts of effector and effector_test, then please merge to that.

content.raw:
The problem was solved by finding the exact gazebo libraries needed for compiling simulator, and for me compiling with gazebo-sensor is not working. I have checked the creation of  GAZEBO_LIBRARIES. We don't need libgazebo.so any more and we need to add libgazebo_sensors.so, so I created new variable based on GAZEBO_LIBRARIES.
I think the issue is similar to the issue reported here [https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/issues/80/building-serverfixture-outside-of-gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/issues/80/building-serverfixture-outside-of-gazebo),
content.html: The problem was solved by finding the exact gazebo libraries needed for compiling simulator, and for me compiling with gazebo-sensor is not working. I have checked the creation of GAZEBO_LIBRARIES. We don't need libgazebo.so any more and we need to add libgazebo_sensors.so, so I created new variable based on GAZEBO_LIBRARIES. I think the issue is similar to the issue reported here https://bitbucket.org/osrf/handsim/issues/80/building-serverfixture-outside-of-gazebo,

content.raw:
Hi Jason, I read the code, I saw that the update() now changes totally and it also handles the process of several agents messages as the previous implementation handles it too. Your code integrates with Agent Class better so some containers in effector class is not needed any more and it has been deleted. I think generally, Now the effector class is integrated with the rest of the classes better, thank you. 
Only one note, In new code,  Update() is executed only once every simulation cycle, In this case we will miss the message information in when an agent sends two messages  during one simulation cycle. I think some messages like init() and Beam() are like an event to the simulator and simulator should know that this messages are sent by the agents. Lets think about a scenario: the agent will send init message and in the same cycle the agent will also send another message, in this case the other message will over write the init message. by the update(), we will not analyse the init message and we will not create that agent. Because of that, I had the idea in previous implementation to update the message in parse() method. I think for the new implementation, it is also possible to move the update to the Parse() method.

I will merge with your branch , I have also implemented the say command parser and am going to commit it after merge. For Effector_test, since now we dont have the data structures and accessors methods of the Effector class, I will test the data imported to agent class.
content.html:
Hi Jason, I read the code, I saw that the update() now changes totally and it also handles the process of several agents messages as the previous implementation handles it too. Your code integrates with Agent Class better so some containers in effector class is not needed any more and it has been deleted. I think generally, Now the effector class is integrated with the rest of the classes better, thank you. Only one note, In new code, Update() is executed only once every simulation cycle, In this case we will miss the message information in when an agent sends two messages during one simulation cycle. I think some messages like init() and Beam() are like an event to the simulator and simulator should know that this messages are sent by the agents. Lets think about a scenario: the agent will send init message and in the same cycle the agent will also send another message, in this case the other message will over write the init message. by the update(), we will not analyse the init message and we will not create that agent. Because of that, I had the idea in previous implementation to update the message in parse() method. I think for the new implementation, it is also possible to move the update to the Parse() method.

I will merge with your branch , I have also implemented the say command parser and am going to commit it after merge. For Effector_test, since now we dont have the data structures and accessors methods of the Effector class, I will test the data imported to agent class.

content.raw:
Hey Nima,

I merged this branch into my integration branch jliang_model. I made some changes to how update is called (it now is called from the robocupplugin and only once every cycle) and removed some unnecessary functions. The code now compiles without any issues. You should merge my branch with yours and continue working from there. 

Also, Effector_TEST is now not compiling due to the changes. I have commented it out for now. 

Here are some things yet to be done:

-Parse the Say S-Expression and put in in gameState->say member variable (for this, you also need to do some additional checks, namely only one agent's message can be broadcasted, alternating between the teams every time effector->Update() is called. Also, you need to check that the message is no longer than 20 bytes long and that it contains only allowed characters). Set gameState->say.isValid to true if there is a legal message to send, else false otherwise.

-Fix the Effector_TEST
content.html:
Hey Nima,

I merged this branch into my integration branch jliang_model. I made some changes to how update is called (it now is called from the robocupplugin and only once every cycle) and removed some unnecessary functions. The code now compiles without any issues. You should merge my branch with yours and continue working from there.

Also, Effector_TEST is now not compiling due to the changes. I have commented it out for now.

Here are some things yet to be done:

-Parse the Say S-Expression and put in in gameState->say member variable (for this, you also need to do some additional checks, namely only one agent's message can be broadcasted, alternating between the teams every time effector->Update() is called. Also, you need to check that the message is no longer than 20 bytes long and that it contains only allowed characters). Set gameState->say.isValid to true if there is a legal message to send, else false otherwise.

-Fix the Effector_TEST

content.raw:
Yes, I can use that one, instead of having update() there between mutex lines we can have vector of messages and call update in other places, in this case it may happen that a message never has been processed by the update(). InitMsg was initially implemented to store init message information for each update and it will be cleared in the update procedure. So we should have map of initMsg with socket_ID in order to store the initMsg to be used if there are any disconnections.
Finally, I can test the implementation of new update() only after I could compile the code with the latest Gazebo, could you compile your branch with the latest Gazebo?

So we should have map of initMsg with socket_ID in order to store the initMsg to be used if there are any disconnections. Finally, I can test the implementation of new update() only after I could compile the code with the latest Gazebo, could you compile your branch with the latest Gazebo?

content.raw:
To clarify, here is the datastructure that should store the messages and socket:
```
#!c++

public: std::map<int, std::string> socketIDMessageMap;

```
The OnConnection() function should create the following key-value entry in socketIDMessageMap:
<socketID, "init">

Similarly, the OnDisconnection() function should check for socketId entry in socketIDMessageMap and set it like so:
<socketID, "delete">
When Parse() is called, it should do the following:

```
#!c++
recv(_socket, buffer);
std::string message(buffer);
<enable mutex>
if (socketIDMessageMap.find(socketId) != socketIDMessageMap.end())
  socketIDMessageMap[socketId] = message;
<disable mutex>
```
It is very important that the insertion operation into socketIDMessageMap is atomic since both the server thread and main thread are accessing this data structure. I dont mind if we still have a update method that is called. effector->Update(), when called from the robocupplugin, will do the following:

0. Clear the agentsToAdd and agentsToRemove vectors.
1. Iterate through all the key-value entries in socketIDMessageMap
2. For each entry, call ParseMessage() on the message string, find the corresponding agent (by iterating through all agents in gameState) that matches the socketId, and update agent.action. 
3. If there are any init messages, push an initMsg object onto the agentsToAdd vector and call gameState->AddAgent(), and set agent.socketId
4. If there are any disconnections (entries with the value "delete"), push an initMsg object onto the agentsToRemove vector and call gameState->RemoveAgent(). Also, delete the entry from socketIDMessageMap.
content.html:
To clarify, here is the datastructure that should store the messages and socket:

public: std::map<int, std::string> socketIDMessageMap;

The OnConnection() function should create the following key-value entry in socketIDMessageMap: <socketID, "init">

Similarly, the OnDisconnection() function should check for socketId entry in socketIDMessageMap and set it like so: <socketID, "delete"> When Parse() is called, it should do the following:

recv(_socket, buffer);
std::string message(buffer);
<enable mutex>
if (socketIDMessageMap.find(socketId) != socketIDMessageMap.end())
  socketIDMessageMap[socketId] = message;
<disable mutex>

It is very important that the insertion operation into socketIDMessageMap is atomic since both the server thread and main thread are accessing this data structure. I dont mind if we still have a update method that is called. effector->Update(), when called from the robocupplugin, will do the following:

  1. Clear the agentsToAdd and agentsToRemove vectors.
  2. Iterate through all the key-value entries in socketIDMessageMap
  3. For each entry, call ParseMessage() on the message string, find the corresponding agent (by iterating through all agents in gameState) that matches the socketId, and update agent.action.
  4. If there are any init messages, push an initMsg object onto the agentsToAdd vector and call gameState->AddAgent(), and set agent.socketId
  5. If there are any disconnections (entries with the value "delete"), push an initMsg object onto the agentsToRemove vector and call gameState->RemoveAgent(). Also, delete the entry from socketIDMessageMap.

content.raw: Hi Nima, I noticed that you only a single message and socketid in the Effector class. I believe we will need a vector of them, one for each agent. Also, you need a mutex around the Parse() method in Effector since it might be called any time by the Server object and we dont want to have race conditions with the Update() method
content.html: Hi Nima, I noticed that you only a single message and socketid in the Effector class. I believe we will need a vector of them, one for each agent. Also, you need a mutex around the Parse() method in Effector since it might be called any time by the Server object and we dont want to have race conditions with the Update() method
